title: Annual Report on Actions to Address Climate Change (2024) released
content_text:
On December 27, 2024, annual report on actions to address climate change (2024) (hereinafter referred to as the Green Book of Climate Change) was released in Beijing, China. It is an authoritative annual publication jointly initiated by the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences (CASS) and the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) and compiled by scholars in the field of climate change in China.
No. 16 Green Book of Climate Change
The Green Book of Climate Change includes important chapters such as general report, new insight of climate change science, the international climate process, domestic policies and actions, industrial transformation, and urban evaluation, and points out that the challenges posed by climate change are becoming increasingly severe and that countries need to strengthen cooperation in the area of green and low-carbon development.
Climate change
The Green Book of Climate Change points out that, at present, the challenge of global climate change to human society is increasingly severe. 2023 is the warmest year since meteorological records began.The global average temperature is about 1.45 ± 0.12 ℃ above pre-industrial levels.And year 2015-2023 are the warmest nine years since meteorological records began. Extreme weather and climate continue to have serious social impacts.
According to The Green Book of Climate Change, China has made remarkable progresses in areas such as renewable energy, electric vehicles and green architecture, while promoting carbon emission reduction through mechanisms such as the carbon emissions trading market. In addition, China has actively participated in international climate cooperation and promoted green development in developing countries through the Belt and Road Initiative.
New technology
The Green Book of Climate Change shows that at present, artificial intelligence (AI) has achieved better application results in the field of climate, and has the potential to be widely applied in the field of addressing climate change. In the future, AI is expected to play a more and more critical role in climate change mitigation, adaptation and other aspects. Besides,  its integration with meteorological disciplines will provide strong scientific and technological support to enhance the accuracy of climate prediction and climate change prediction.
Carrying out meteorological early warning is an effective approach to enhance climate change adaptation capacity and promote sustainable development. The Green Book of Climate Change shows that Africa, as one of the regions most seriously threatened by climate change, has been severely affected by the frequent occurrence of extreme weather events and intensified climate disasters in recent years, seriously affecting the production and life of African people, so international cooperation and broad multi-partner engagement are required. Under the framework ofinitiatives of the United Nations (UN) and others, some countries and international organizations have provided Africa with relevant mechanisms, initiatives and projects to jointly promote the realization of Early Warnings for All Initiative of UN, which has enabled a significant improvement in the early warning capacity of African countries.
“Dual carbon” goal
New quality productive forcesare a kind of green productivity. Since China put forward “dual carbon”goal, it has formulated a “1+N” policy system of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality with“dual carbon” as an important starting point, providing a powerful impetus for the development of New quality productive forces and achieved positive results which deserve global recognition.
The Green Book of Climate Change showcases that China's green and low-carbon transportation policies have been effective in reducing greenhouse gas emissions, increasing the resilience of the transportation system, and promoting sustainable development, thus providing experience for the global response to climate change. By optimizing the transportation structure, promoting low-carbon facilities and strengthening pollution prevention and control, China is gradually achieving a low-carbon and efficient traffic system, and promoting the achievement of “dual carbon” goal.

title: WMO confirms 2024 as warmest year on record at about 1.55°C above pre-industrial level
content_text:
The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has confirmed that 2024 is the warmest year on record, based on six international datasets. The past ten years have all been in the Top Ten, in an extraordinary streak of record-breaking temperatures.
Ed Hawkins
The global average surface temperature was 1.55 °C  (with a margin of uncertainty of ± 0.13 °C) above the 1850-1900 average, according to WMO’s consolidated analysis of the six datasets. This means that we have likely just experienced the first calendar year with a global mean temperature of more than 1.5°C above the 1850-1900 average.
“Today’s assessment from the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) proves yet again – global heating is a cold, hard fact,” said UN Secretary-General Antóno Guterres.
“Individual years pushing past the 1.5 degree limit do not mean the long-term goal is shot. It means we need to fight even harder to get on track. Blazing temperatures in 2024 require trail-blazing climate action in 2025,” he said. “There's still time to avoid the worst of climate catastrophe. But leaders must act – now,” he said.
The WMO provides a temperature assessment based on multiple sources of data to support international climate monitoring and to provide authoritative information for the UN Climate Change negotiating process. The datasets are from the European Center for Medium Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF), Japan Meteorological Agency, NASA, the US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), the UK’s Met Office in collaboration with the Climatic Research Unit at the University of East Anglia (HadCRUT), and Berkeley Earth.
“Climate history is playing out before our eyes. We’ve had not just one or two record-breaking years, but a full ten-year series. This has been accompanied by devastating and extreme weather, rising sea levels and melting ice, all powered by record-breaking greenhouse gas levels due to human activities,” said WMO Secretary-General Celeste Saulo.
“It is important to emphasize that a single year of more than 1.5°C for a year does NOT mean that we have failed to meet Paris Agreement long-term temperature goals, which are measured over decades rather than an individual year. However, it is essential to recognize that every fraction of a degree of warming matters. Whether it is at a level below or above 1.5°C of warming, every additional increment of global warming increases the impacts on our lives, economies and our planet,” said Celeste Saulo.
There is a margin of uncertainty in all temperature assessments. All six datasets place 2024 as the warmest year on record and all highlight the recent rate of warming. But not all show the temperature anomaly above 1.5 °C due to differing methodologies.
The timing of the release of the six temperature datasets was coordinated across the institutions in order to underline the exceptional conditions experienced during 2024.
A separate study published in Advances in Atmospheric Sciences found that ocean warming in 2024 played a key role in the record high temperatures. The ocean is the warmest it has ever been as recorded by humans, not only at the surface but also for the upper 2000 meters, according to the study led by Prof. Lijing Cheng with the Institute of Atmospheric Physics at the Chinese Academy of Sciences. It involved a team of 54 scientists from seven countries and 31 institutes.
About 90% of the excess heat from global warming is stored in the ocean, making ocean heat content a critical indicator of climate change. From 2023 to 2024, the global upper 2000 m ocean heat content increase is 16 zettajoules (1021 Joules), about 140 times the world’s total electricity generation in 2023, according to the study, which is based on the Insitute of Atmospheric Physics dataset.
WMO will provide full details of key climate change indicators, including greenhouse gases, surface temperatures, ocean heat, sea level rise, glacier retreat and sea ice extent, in its State of the Global Climate 2024 report to be issued in March 2025. This will also give details of high-impact events.
Source: WMO

title: WMO: Report: How climate insights drive a more reliable renewable energy transition
content_text:
As the global transition to renewable energy accelerates, weather and climate insights are becoming increasingly important to ensure the reliability and resilience of energy systems and planning of electricity demand and supplies, according to a new report.
2023 Year in Review: Climate-driven Global Renewable Energy Potential Resources and Energy Demand finds that climate-informed and diversified energy solutions are essential if the world is to meet targets to triple renewable energy capacity and double energy efficiency by 2030.
The report was jointly produced by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO), the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA) and the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S), operated by the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF).
“Whether it is solar power generation in drier-than-average conditions, wind power generation in regions experiencing shifts from La Niña to El Niño conditions, or hydropower generation in the face of fluctuating precipitation patterns, climate has a direct bearing on both electricity supply and demand. Such challenges also present unprecedented opportunities: the integration of climate insights into energy planning yields more reliable power generation, helps anticipate seasonal peaks in demand and strengthens the adaptability of future infrastructure development,” write WMO Secretary-General Celeste Saulo, IRENA Director-General Francesco Camera and C3S Director Carlo Buontempo in a joint foreword.
The report looks at 2023 – a year which saw a transition from a La Niña to an El Niño phenomena, affecting key climatic variables for the energy sector such as wind speed, solar radiation, precipitation and temperature. It was also the warmest year on record, until this record was broken again in 2024.
It was released ahead of the Sustainable Energy for All Global Forum in Barbados on 12-13 March.
Source: WMO

title: Chengdu: Why is this AI weather model get its name from a stone rhinoceros?
content_text:
More than 2,000 years ago, LI Bing, a famous water conservancy expert in the Warring States period left the stone rhinoceros to guard a side of the water and soil peace in Chengdu, Sichuan, China. More than 2,000 years later, Chengdu Municipal Meteorological Department joined hands with the Qinghai-Xizang Plateau Meteorological Research Institute, the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) to create an artificial intelligence (AI) weather model of local short-range forecast “Rongcheng - Lingxi (means wise rhinoceros in Chinese)”(hereafter referred to as the Model), and continued to write a new chapter of meteorological disaster prevention and mitigation.
In March 2024, the Model was formally put into operation, which is based on AI technology to realize the next 2 hours of time resolution of 6 minutes, spatial resolution as fine as 1 km radar combination of reflectivity extrapolation forecast. With the rapid updating of forecasts, the 0-2 hour rainfall forecast is as fine as 5 min and 100 m.
The basic core of the Model originates from the physical constraints-based radar combined reflectivity factor extrapolation algorithm, which realizes the accurate analysis and prediction of meteorological data through the training and testing of deep neural network model.
Moreover, its innovative core lies in the Model's ability to integrate multiple meteorological elements and capture long-term dependencies and short-term dynamic changes in the time series through the memory module and perceptual attention mechanism, which effectively improves the extrapolation capability of radar echoes. Through the motion feature extraction and perceptual attention, the Model shows good prediction effect in dealing with complex meteorological systems, especially severe convective weather, and the prediction capability is improved by 5% compared with that of traditional models.
At midnight on July 23, 2024, locally short-term heavy precipitation occurred in the western mountains of Chengdu. After the discussions between city and county-level meteorological departments, 5 cities (counties)  issued a red rainstorm warning signal 90 minutes in advance
according to the forecast conclusions of the Model
. The forecast of the Model was highly consistent with the actual situation, which confirmed the good prediction performance of the short-term model on the development and movement of mesoscale convective systems under complex terrain.

title: Spotlight on CMA’s AI-enabled meteorological applications
content_text:
On June 16, the promise of Artificial Intelligence (AI) to revolutionize forecasts and help build resilience to more extreme weather and climate impacts is high on the agenda of the 79th Session of the World Meteorological Organization (WMO)' s Executive Council.
Starting from 2024, the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) has collaborated with domestic and international meteorological departments, universities, and research institutions to strengthen the AI-abled application in meteorological monitoring, forecasting, warning and services, providing vigorous technological support for the United Nations' Early Warnings for All (EW4ALL) initiative and meteorological disaster prevention and mitigation.
4 AI-abled weather models
Al Nowcasting Model (CMA-AIM-Nowcast-Fenglei)
CMA and Tsinghua University jointly build “Fenglei”, which can provide information on the generation, dissipation and evolution of the convective storms in response to common issues in global nowcasting.
It is possible to generate a national radar echo extrapolation product of 1 kilometer for 0-3 hours every 6 minutes on Tianqing system within 3 minutes.
The Technical Architecture of Fenglei
Al Global Weather Forecast Model (CMA-AIM-GFS-Fengqing)
CMA and Tsinghua University set up a research team to establish "Fengqing".
This model achieves a deep integration of atmospheric physics and data-driven methods, enabling efficient computation while providing a physically interpretable basis for prediction results.
lt can generate global forecasts of atmospheric variables such as precipitation, wind, and temperature with a 25-kilometer resolution every 6 hours for the next 15 days within 3 minutes, providing detailed and accurate weather information for people's daily lives, travel, and tourism.

AI Global Climate Forecasting Model (CMA-AIM-S2S-Fengshun)
CMA cooperated with Fudan University and the Shanghai Academy of Artificial Intelligence Science, and build “Fengshun” based on AI.
The model runs daily to provide 100 ensemble members for the next 60 days with significantly higher computational efficiency, which also takes atmosphere-ocean coupling into consideration, thus enhancing the prediction skills of Madden–Julian Oscillation (MJO).

AI Space Weather Forecasting Model (CMA-AIM-SW-Fengyu)
CMA jointly researched and developed "Fengyu" with Nanchang University and Huawei Technologies Co Ltd.
The model includes a full-chain AI model for space weather, covering multiple physical regions such as solar wind, magnetosphere and ionosphere. It also is equipped with core functions such as ionospheric disturbance prediction, geomagneticstorm response, and solar wind forecasting.
The Technical Architecture of "Fengyu"
Cloud-based Early Warning System
Focusing on the 4 pillars of EW4ALL- Disaster risk knowledge, Detection, observation, monitoring, analysis, and forecasting, Warning dissemination and communication, and Preparedness and response capabilities, Cloud-based Early Warning System incorporates AI technology and meteorological forecasting models to support the development of disaster warning capabilities in developing countries.
The System has been applied in countries including Pakistan, Ethiopia, and the Solomon Islands.

Urban Multi-hazard Early Warning Toolbox is equipped with a comprehensive set of institutional tools, algorithmic models, business system tools, and case studies based on 4 pillars of EW4ALL. It also features 5 major application scenarios: data intelligent compression, forecast intelligent analysis, multi-scenario assessment coordination, automatic collection of disaster situation reports, and disaster prevention knowledge dissemination.
Currently, the Toolbox has been in trial application in 12 countries and regions, covering multiple disaster scenarios such as urban flooding, typhoons and rainstorm.

title: The multi-platform comprehensive observation experiment of meteorological processes inducing disasters on the Qinghai-Xizang plateau kicked off
content_text:
On July 21, Institute of Qinghai-Xizang Plateau Meteorology, in collaboration with departments like Sichuan Provincial Meteorological Service, the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) Meteorological Observation Centre (MOC),
Qinghai Provincial and
Xizang Autonomous Region Meteorological Service, and Chengdu University of Information Technology, kicked off a multi-platform comprehensive observation experiment to study disaster-inducing meteorological processes over the plateau.
The eastern Qinghai-Xizang Plateau serves as the "gateway" to the "Asian Water Tower." This region is not only a major precipitation zone but also the source of disaster-inducing weather systems, such as plateau vortices and southwest vortices.
The experiment employs a coordinated observing approach, integrating ground-based observation networks, airborne unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), and space-based satellites, enhancing early warning capabilities for meteorological disasters, and providing services for the World Games 2025.
This experiment has harnessed a coordinated ground-air-space observation to conduct multi-scale observations ranging from 300 km down to 30 km, in a bid to provide critical data for improving numerical weather prediction (NWP) models and enhance precipitation forecasting accuracy.
UAVs have conducted operations like vertical temperature and humidity sounding observation and laser wind measurement observation.

title: Journal of Meteorological Research 丨Travel through the centenary of JMR
content_text:
In 1925, as dawn “touched” the century-old dome of Qingdao Observatory in Shandong, the Journal of the Chinese Meteorological Society (JCMS), the predecessor to today's Journal of Meteorological Research (JMR)— was launched. The JCMS Editorial Office was sited at Qingdao Observatory.
In October 1934, a special issue was published in memory of the 10th anniversary of the CMS. The JCMS Editorial Office was relocated to Beijing in Nanjing.
On April 2 1941, the 4th editorial committee meeting proposed that Meteorological Magazine be changed into Acta Meteorologica Sinica (AMS) and each article be published with an English abstract starting from Vol. 15. The Editorial Office was moved to Xiangzhuang, Beipei, Chongqing.
In 1962, the Editorial Office was moved to No. 7 Wuta Temple, Beijing and stationed there ever after (the street was renamed to be the current one later).
In September 1987, AMS English Edition was officially launched.
In 1996, AMS changed from quarterly into bimonthly.
In 2014, AMS English Edition (Acta Meteorologica Sinica) was renamed as Journal of Meteorological Research (JMR)，with a new ISSN 2095-6037, and a new Editorial Board (The Board started to try run since October 2012).
Over a century, ZHU Kezhen's curve has become pivotal in global climate studies; TU Changwang first integrated China's data into worldwide climate research; YE Duzheng decoded the Qinghai-Xizang Plateau's "thermal dynamics" to explain East Asian monsoons. Each volume of JMR bears tenacious and pioneering imprints.
From its first article to the Sicence Citation Index (SCI) -indexed English edition, China's meteorology has gradually gained prominence on the globe stage. From ink-smudged pages to refined prints, JMR chronicles the meteorological scientific progress; from mimeographed sheets to instant digital access, it constantly mirrors China's technological rise. From irregular issues to bimonthly issues, its Chinese and English editions make their presence worldwide. Every page-turn expands meteorology's horizons and arouses civilization's dialogue.
More than a mere publication, JMR incubates paradigm shifts and chronicles the growth of China's meteorological talents.
Planned by/Editor: LIU Shuqiao

Where the floods are and how to prevent?

title: China's local early warning practice丨Guangxi gives full play to the role of progressive meteorological service in tacking Typhoon Wutip
content_text:
Since June 12, affected by Typhoon Wutip, rainstorm to torrential rain and locally extremely downpour have occurred in eastern Guangxi, China.
According to statistics, the maximum cumulative rainfall registered 371.2 mm in Shapo Town, Luchuan County, Yulin, Guangxi. Winds of scale 8 or above have appeared in the Beibu Gulf, the coastal areas of southern Guangxi and eastern Guangxi, with the maximum recorded as 29.7 meters per second (grade 11) at Yangwei Ridge, Jieyang Island.
Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Regional Meteorological Service (hereinafter referred to as the Service) released level-four warning of Typhoon on June 11, and upgraded to level-three on June 12 to tackle the weather process. It also issued level-four warning of rainstorm on June 14. On June 15, it upgraded the two warnings concerning the diminishing impacts of the weather process.
The Service also reinforce communication and interactions with other departments. It has jointly issued 8 meteorological risk warnings of geological disasters and mountain torrents in collaboration with the Department of Natural Resources, the Department of Water Resources, and the Water Resources Center of Guangxi. Daily highway traffic risk warning tips were also jointly released with the transportation and traffic police departments.
Guangxi emergency response decision-making assistance system Source: The Service
Meteorological departments across Guangxi have called and alerted more than 4,000 primary-level emergency responders via telephone and “Shanxin”messages.
Beihai and Nanning have carried out Beidou Drifting Sounding and intensive sounding, utilizing real-time observation data from manned aircraft, dropped sounding, weather radar, and wind profile radar of Hong Kong Observatory to achieve comprehensive and coordinated observation of long-distance  precise typhoon early warning and close-range observation.
According to meteorological information, during the impacts of the Typhoon, Guangxi Maritime Administration of People's Republic of China activated the highest-level typhoon emergency response look into potential risk. Other departments such as natural resources, and water resources have activated corresponding levels of emergency responses.
Guangxi emergency response decision-making assistance system Source: The Service
Ships at sea have returned to port to take shelter from the wind, trains on many routes have been suspended, and relevant personnel have been relocated and resettled in advance in various places of Guangxi.
From June 11 to 15, various departments across Guangxi have issued 472 early warning text messages through the Guangxi Emergency Early Warning Information Release System, with 76.02 million recipients. Loudspeakers were harnessed to release warnings 31,200 times.
Progressive meteorological service given full play in Weizhou Island
“It was a narrow escape. Thanks to the accurate forecast of the meteorological department, we were able to evacuate safely from Weizhou Island!”The tourist said with lingering fear as he got off the boat.
At 11:50 on June 12, with the last passenger ship, "Beiyou 15", blaring its horn and berthing at the port, the Weizhou Island to Beihai passenger route successfully completed 12 evacuation tasks, safely escorting nearly 10,000 tourists away from the island before the arrival of Typhoon Wutip.
Beihai Municipal Meteorological Department (hereinafter referred to as the Department), Guangxi initiated progressive meteorological service mechanism. The refined forecasting of air routes served as the "baton" for adjusting the evacuation plan, buying precious time for the safe evacuation of tourists. The round-trip route between Beihai and Weizhou Island has also been completely suspended since noon on June 12.
At noon on June 12, the local maritime administration completed the safe evacuation of tourists from Weizhou Island. Source: Guangxi Transport Bureau
On June 10, in the Beibu Gulf, the water was rippling and tourists came in a continuous stream. On that day, the Department pointed out that a tropical depression had formed over the South China Sea and was about to become No.1 Typhoon Wutip of this year. There would be obvious wind and rain on the sea surface of Beihai Sea and the Beibu Gulf, and precautions needed to be boosted.
On June 11, LIANG Baorong, Director of Beihai Municipal Meteorological Observatory (hereinafter referred to as the Observatory), kept an eye on the constantly updated track of the typhoon and issued instructions resolutely. Immediately, the Department initiated a level-four emergency response and held joint consultations with multiple departments including emergency management, oceanography, water resources, and hydrology to tackle the impacts of Wutip.
LIANG Baorong led his team to provide hourly sea surface wind force and visibility forecasts for the normal operation of the Beihai-Weizhou Island route on an updated basis, while closely monitoring the typhoon's movement to capture the crucial window period for the final evacuation of tourists.
At 16:30 on June 11, the Observatory issued a special warning for the Beihai-Weizhou Island route for the first time.
After receiving the meteorological warning information, the Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters Office of Weizhou Island Tourist Scenic Area issued the No. 1 emergency notice of the year, requiring tourists on the island to take a ship to leave the island before noon on June 12, and residents on the island to strictly implement typhoon prevention measures. At the same time, relevant departments quickly activated emergency responses, adjusted and increased shifts, and assembled passenger ships to evacuate tourists.
The local maritime administration assisted in transferring injured passengers on Weizhou Island. Source: Guangxi Transportation Bureau
At the night of June 11, the Observatory was brightly lit, with large screens displaying various monitoring data such as typhoon tracks, sea wind fields, and precipitation on a real-time basis.
Forecasters intently fixated their eyes on the fluctuating meteorological data, analyzed the weather condition, and continuously updated and refined forecasts for sea wind force and visibility, effectively ensuring the navigation safety of return passenger ships in complex sea conditions.
On June 14, Typhoon Wutip arrived, and passenger ships on the Beihai-Weizhou Island route docked at the port in an orderly manner. Photo credits to Beihai Xinyi Cruise Co., LTD
On June 15, after two days of suspension, the Beihai-Weizhou Island route resumed its usual bustling scene.

title: China's local early warning practice丨Guizhou's progressive meteorological service has supported flood control and prevention in Rongjiang County
content_text:
On June 28, the Flood Control and Drought Relief Command of Rongjiang County Government in Qiandongnan Miao and Dong Autonomous Prefecture, Guizhou, China, issued a notice upgrading the flood control emergency response from level 2 to level 1, requiring all personnel in seven flood-prone areas to evacuate.
Forecasters of the Prefecture Meteorological Observatory monitored rainfall and analyze future weather conditions. Photoed by YANG Changda
Meteorological departments in Guizhou implemented a “24631” progressive meteorological service mechanism, closely coordinating warning issuance with government emergency responses. This mechanism has provided valuable time for the evacuation and relocation of residents, science-based reservoir management, and the precise deployment of rescue forces.
The “24631” progressive meteorological service involves issuing detailed forecasts for heavy rainfall over the next 24 hours at the city, county, and township level in advance, initiating weather consultations every 6 hours, updating short-range forecasts of heavy rainfall for the next 3 hours every 3 hours, and updating short-range forecasts of heavy rainfall for the next 3 hours every hour.
In response to this flood, Guizhou Provincial Meteorological Service activated an emergency response at 11:00 on June 24, and the Guizhou Provincial Meteorological Observatory continuously provided rolling updates on major meteorological information. During the peak period of heavy rainfall on June 28, the Observatory provided meteorological services to the rescue operations in Rongjiang County every 3 hours, with updates every hour. The relevant information was directly transmitted to the Emergency Command Centre of Department of Emergency Management of Guizhou Province, providing a basis for decision-making for the flood control coordination work of the Provincial Government.
Qiandongnan Prefectural Meteorological Department issued a weather information report at 15:00 on June 27, forecasting a trend of heavy rainfall. The warning signal was rapidly upgraded: A blue warning for heavy rain across the Prefecture was issued at 17:30 on June 27, upgraded to an orange warning at 07:25 on June 28, and decisively elevated to the highest-level red warning at 09:25. Emergency response measures were simultaneously upgraded: A Level 4 response was initiated at 17:00 on June 27, upgraded to Level 3 at 07:30 on June 28, and further upgraded to Level 1 at 09:50.
Meteorological offices in counties such as Rongjiang, Danzhai, and Leishan, which were at the core of the heavy rainfall, acted swiftly upon receiving flood warnings and issued 19 heavy rainfall warning signals by the early morning of June 28. Staff from Danzhai and Leishan Meteorological Offices went to the local emergency management bureaus for joint work during the peak period of heavy rainfall, providing precise and timely meteorological service data for frontline rescue and disaster relief efforts. Since June 25, Rongjiang County Meteorological Office has established 3 meteorological service teams responsible for operations, support, and rescue work, respectively, to continuously update warning information, ensure the stable operation of meteorological operational systems, and conduct road clearance and drainage system maintenance.
In this response to the rainstorm, the provincial, municipal, and county meteorological departments worked together efficiently, with early warnings closely coordinated with government emergency responses, providing valuable time for personnel evacuation, science-based reservoir management, and the precise deployment of rescue strengths.

title: The AI Agent for Multi-Hazard Early Warning: MAZU-Urban unveiled at the 2025 WAIC
content_text:
On July 26, at the opening ceremony of the 2025 World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC), the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) launched MAZU, a Joint Action for Early Warnings for All. Witnessed by Prof. Celeste Saulo, WMO Secretary-General and other guests, Dr. CHEN Zhenlin, Administrator of CMA, donated the AI Agent for Multi-Hazard Early Warning: MAZU-Urban to representatives from Djibouti and Mongolia. This marks the official launch of the System, which deeply integrates artificial intelligence (AI) technology with meteorological science, as it embarks on its cross-border mission of meteorological disaster prevention and mitigation.
The interface of MAZU-Urban Source: SMS
Under the framework of MAZU, MAZU-Urban was jointly developed by the Shanghai Meteorological Service (SMS), the National Meteorological Centre of CMA, China United Network Communications Co., Ltd. Shanghai Branch, the Shanghai Institute of Science and Intelligence, and the Shanghai Artificial Intelligence Laboratory. As the urban user end of CMA's early warning support operational system, with AI technology as its core, it deeply integrates advanced algorithms and multi-source data, and is equipped with cloud-based early warning system products, meteorological open-source models, and the African regional model developed by SMS.
MAZU-Urban creatively builds a smart architecture that integrates host, tablet, and mobile devices into a “3-in-1” framework: The all-in-one device serves meteorological and emergency management departments, integrating international standards with local guidelines to enhance risk awareness and monitoring and forecasting capabilities, supporting minute-level disaster data collection and the generation of localized defense guidelines. The tablet device focuses on the needs of users in industries such as port and shipping, combining multi-source observations and user thresholds to provide customized meteorological risk assessments. And the mobile device is aimed at the public, using location-based alerts to notify users of nearby disasters and providing evacuation guidelines, emergency shelter navigation, and emergency contact information. Since January this year, MAZU-Urban has been piloted in 35 countries and territories across Asia, Africa, and Oceania, and been well-received.
MAZU-Urban's technological core aligns with the four pillars of Early Warnings for All (EW4All): In disaster risk knowledge, it supports online access to multi-hazard early warning risk assessment technical solutions and related databases; in detection, observation, monitoring, analysis, and forecasting, it provides flexible multi-hazard monitoring tools and forecast application analysis tools; in warning dissemination and communication, it can intelligently generate disaster condition reports; in preparedness and response capabilities, it can generate role-based and disaster-specific defense guidelines and emergency plans based on AI language models, and support interactive Q&A, significantly improving response efficiency.
With the support of CMA MAZU-Urban is the first globally shared product researched and developed by SMS. In the future, SMS will accelerate joint construction of meteorological early warning operational system based on cities, and contribute more Shanghai experience and Chinese solutions to the global meteorological disaster prevention and mitigation.

title: Local early warning practice of China丨Meteorological departments of Shaanxi build a "life-saving levee" for flood prevention

In July, Shaanxi, China experienced a rapid shift from drought to flood. Despite enduring extensive heat wave with record-breaking temperatures in multiple areas within the province, Shaanxi has also been confronted with widespread heavy rainfall, torrential rain and downpours occurring in succession.
In Shangluo, Shaanxi, 5 rivers experienced six flood peaks, with two exceeding warning levels—creating an extremely severe flood prevention condition. Leveraging a municipal and county-level "3-in-1" disaster prevention and mitigation command platform (hereinafter referred to as the Platform), which integrating meteorological services, emergency flood control, and primary level comprehensive management with "man-to-man" and "prevention, emergency response, and evacuation" mechanisms, providing valuable response time for flood control.
The procedure of the “13161” Mechanism Credits to Shaanxi Provincial Meteorological Service
In recent years, Shangluo has been improving its work mechanism led by meteorological warnings. With the optimization of “13161” progressive meteorological service mechanism (hereinafter referred to as the “13161” Mechanism) and “call and response” mechanism, how to make departmental collaboration more efficient, and command and dispatch more timely becomes the key to addressing disaster prevention problems.
The main functions of the Platform Source: Shangluo Municipal Meteorological Department
By 08:00 on July 10, Shangluo had evacuated 10,481 residents from 5,609 households in high-risk zones, ensuring the safety of the people.
Besides, on July 9, Shanyang County Meteorological Observatory in Shangluo issued a red warning signal of rainstorm at 07:49, followed by two more red warning signals at 08:35. and 10:00 respectively. Using the Platform to identify key risk zones, relevant departments arranged emergency response and deployments. Responsible persons and supporting officials of departments also rushed to the scene for flood response.
In Xixiang County, Hanzhong, on the afternoon of July 17, heavy rain occurred. All 33 monitoring stations in the county recorded significant precipitation, with a maximum cumulative rainfall of 89.1 mm and peak hourly rainfall reaching 81.8 mm.
During response to the heavy rainfall, Xixiang County Meteorological Office also implemented the Mechanism, issued important weather reports and warning signals in advance, rolling out real-time rainfall and trend updates, and releasing 11 rounds of forecasts and warnings. All the above-mentioned information has reached emergency management departments and township (street) coordinators via SMS, WeChat groups, emergency broadcast systems, and local media, gaining critical time for county-wide flood response and evacuations.
On the afternoon of July 17, severe convective weather occurred in Xixiang County, with some areas experiencing short-range heavy rainfall. The on-duty personnel were preparing service materials and using “call and response” mechanism to the involved towns. Photoed by HUANG Wei
From July 19 to 20, Xi'an was met with its heaviest rainfall this year. In the line with the “13161” Mechanism, Xi'an Municipal Meteorological Department responded proactively, taking prompt measures such as issuing a weekly outlook highlighting risks on July 14, upgrading severe convective weather emergency response to level 2 on July 17.
At 11:00 on July 19, after issuing a key high-impact forecast, Xi'an Municipal Meteorological Observatory rolled out 5 updates—including yellow/red thunderstorm and wind /rainstorm warning signals. And it also issued 20 early warnings signals to secure response time of 114 minutes for Lintong District , and guided Lantian County issued an orange rainstorm warning signal 95 minutes ahead of impact.

Meteorological
Service
In the meanwhile, Xi'an Municipal Meteorological Department immediately notified the government and  multi-departmental actions followed immediately. Water-related departments and drainage groups remained on high alert at rivers, reservoirs, and flood-prone sites. Meteorological departments issued joint warning signals with natural resources, emergency, and water departments triggering 258 hazard-point inspections. And culture and tourism departments closed down 24 mountain attractions and 897 rural lodges, evacuating tourists.
Meteorological warning signals have guided primary-level actions. 6 mountain-adjacent districts closed 134 mountain passes 12 hours in advance, evacuating 3,728 residents. And minute-scale forecasts for urban waterlogging points helped drain 6 deep inundation sites within three hours.
Moving forward, the Service will optimize the “13161” Mechanism and “call and response” mechanism, take proactive measures to enable earlier detection, forecasting, warning, and response to severe weather, and also accelerate FENGYUN meteorological satellite data services, refining extreme weather/climate event response, and enhancing global agro-meteorological service capability.

title: The World Games丨Chengdu Municipal Meteorological Department: Predicting the Unpredictable to Ensure a Spectacular Event
content_text:
From August 7 to 17, the World Games 2025 is held in Chengdu, Sichuan, China. To better ensure the highest-level international comprehensive sports event for non-Olympic disciplines, Chengdu Municipal Meteorological Department (hereinafter referred to as the Department) of Sichuan has leveraged technology to build a high-precision, intelligent weather supporting system to deliver more tailored services for the event and the smooth operation of the city.
Precise Monitoring: Establishing a comprehensive network to track weather conditions
The uniqueness of the World Games lies in the fact that the opening and closing ceremonies, as well as 18 out of the 34 events, are held outdoors. Weather elements such as temperature, humidity, wind, and precipitation can significantly impact the events, which calls for more accurate and timely meteorological information.Therefore, the Department has established a multi-layered, high-density monitoring network. Building on the existing 61 weather stations, 26 new monitoring stations have been added, including 7 laser wind-measuring radars with a spatial resolution refined to 15 m, enabling second-scale three-dimensional (3D) data collection for wind, temperature, and humidity.
The system also incorporates the China Meteorological Administration (CMA)'s ground-based remote sensing vertical observation system, which provides minute-scale vertical profiles of temperature, humidity, and wind direction from the ground up to 10 km in altitude.
Additionally, FENGYUN-4B meteorological satellite has performed continuous scans at 1-minute interval, with 13 operational upper-air stations conducting four to eight daily soundings, and Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) and multi-radar networks working in coordination. This has laid a solid foundation for the application of meteorological "digital twin" technology.
"Digital Twin": Simulating weather risks in virtual venues
The Department has innovatively applied "digital twin" technology, using computational fluid dynamics (CFD) and 3D visualization modeling to recreate the core areas of the opening ceremony, integrating meteorological elements with event scenarios. The National Meteorological Information Centre (NMIC) of CMA, in collaboration with Sichuan Municipal Meteorological Observation Data Centre and the Department, has developed a 3D wind field analysis product with a resolution of 5 meters, capable of accurately capturing complex wind patterns. A "digital twin" meteorological field with a grid resolution of 10 m at 5-second interval.
It is informed that this has made the event operations and weather risks visually synchronized, allowing organizers to quickly and clearly grasp weather conditions and their potential impacts, underpinning science-based deployment.
"One Event, One Strategy": AI-Driven Precision Services
To meet the diverse needs of the 34 events, the Department has introduced a "One event, One strategy" service model, offering a catalog of 10 categories and 19 types of products.
From pre-event weather monitoring to minute-scale forecast updates during competitions, and short-range warnings for sudden weather changes, the system has ensured the comprehensive coverage.
For instance,at water-based venues like Xinglong Lake and Sancha Lake, the "World Games Connect" App provides real-time weather updates, and meteorological liaison officers deliver specialized bilingual forecasts at 08:00on a daily basis, helping organizers manage critical indicators such as wind speed and visibility on the lake surface.
By harnessing artificial intelligence (AI) to analyze real-time monitoring data, the team can generate risk warnings and produce hyper-local, minute-scale precise forecasts, the accuracy of key period forecasts to 91%.
Next, Chengdu will inherit a denser network of meteorological observation stations, a smarter "digital twin" platform, and enhance scenario-based service capabilities, which will refine the meteorological servicesfrom event support to urban operations, continuously empowering Chengdu's smart development.

title: Early warning practice of China丨Meteorological defense line built to respond to the impacts of Typhoon Podul
content_text:
At 13:00 on August 13, Typhoon Podul slammed ashore near Taimali Township in Taitung County, Taiwan, with its 45-metre-per-second eyewall whipping the coastline with ferocious swells and torrential rain.
Just prior to that, the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) activated a level-three emergency responses at 09:40 on Monday, August 11 in response to the upcoming typhoon. What followed was a tightly choreographed, three-tier operation that moved from supercomputers and meteorological satellites in Beijing to village loudspeakers in the storm's projected path.
Inside the National Meteorological Centre (NMC) of CMA, chief forecasters sat around a 30-metre curved display, feeding an ensemble of new data streams into machine-learning "typhoon-intensity" algorithms. They also conducted joint weather consultation with meteorological departments of Shanghai, Zhejiang, Fujian and Guangdong to diagnose the track and impacts of Typhoon Podul.
The National Satellite Meteorological Centre (NSMC) of CMA fused FENGYUN-4B high-resolution visible and infrared imagery with FY-3G’s three-dimensional (3D) precipitation radar and FY-3E's surface-wind scatterometer，taking on a cloud-to-ocean,  view updated every ten minutes.
The image captured by FY satellites Source: NSMC
The National Meteorological Information Centre (NMIC) of CMA churned out real-time grids of maximum wind, sea-surface temperature and ocean heat content. Vortex-initialization routines nudged the typhoon centre within each model cycle to within a 2-kilometer margin of error.
In the meanwhile, the CMA Meteorological Observation Centre compiled radar composites from 140 sites under the "Tianheng-Tianyan" framework, cross-checking forecasts against live wind-radar data while remotely diagnosing instrument health across the entire emergency zone.
Guangdong, on the night of August 12, pushed typhoon-defense messages to about 190 million mobile users across all 21 prefectures through a single emergency cell broadcast.
Fujian, by August 13 noon, had 281 fishing boats back in harbour, 1,252 non-essential aquaculture workers safely ashore, 9,438 officials deployed to villages and 73 residents in high-risk zones relocated.
